turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Action/2015.
turn.1: What did the leaders of Action/2015 do?
turn.2: They called for authentic leadership from you, leadership with integrity, leadership from the heart.
turn.4: I know that you can live up to their hopes.” On 28 and 29 November 2015, as governments of over 190 countries prepared to deliver a historic new global climate agreement at COP21 in Paris, the action/2015 movement joined with thousands around the world for the Global Climate March.
turn.6: 785,000 people marched at over 2,300 events in 175 countries, making it the biggest climate mobilisation in history.
turn.7: What are some examples of this?
turn.8: This included over 60,000 people in Melbourne, 100,000 in India, over 50,000 in London, 2,500 in Chile, and over 20,000 in Malawi.
turn.9: Did they have any other successes?
turn.10: In Uganda, action/2015 was a key organiser of the Climate March in Kampala, echoing the call for climate action from Pope Francis, who was in the country as part of his first trip to Africa.
